awd_titl_txt: RAPID:   Presidentialism, Democratic Collapse and the Potential Rise of a One-Party State.
awd_abstract_narration:
General Summary

This study seeks to answer two questions: (1) what influences political elites to support and oppose a transformation from a parliamentary democracy to a presidential democracy and, (2) what influences political elites in a democracy to support or oppose a transition to a non-democratic one-party state. Existing theories explain elite preference for presidential systems as a result of political insecurity of ruling party elites and, ideological and policy radicalization among all political elites. Existing theories that seek to explain why democracies collapse assign the beliefs of ruling party elites regarding the security of their political power, structural factors such as poverty and ethnic radicalization and, international factors such as regional wars and foreign aid central roles in their theories. Political events in the last 25 years show that parties have been important in changing regimes and in undermining democracies. In this project, examines the questions of presidential choice and democratic collapse by surveying political elites--candidates aspiring to hold elected office in parliament in Turkey. Interviewing this set of MP candidates offers a unique opportunity to evaluate the incentive structures and decision-making process of parliamentary members who will decide the question of Turkey's transformation from a parliamentary to a presidential governance system. These elite-survey data on the beliefs, preferences and calculations allows for the testing of existing and new theories on parliamentarism/presidentialism and democratic collapse not possible previously because of lack of elite-level data. 

Technical Summary

In this project, the PI proposes to collect elite-level survey data that will allow her to test existing and new theories related to two important questions: (1) what influences political elites to support and oppose a transformation from a parliamentary democracy to a presidential democracy and, (2) what influences political elites in a democracy to support or oppose a transition to a non-democratic one-party state. Extant research in the literatures on political institutions and democratic collapse identify the insecurity of ruling party elites regarding their grip on political powers, ideological and policy radicalization among elites and structural factors such as poverty and ethnic polarization as key determinants influencing elites to choose a presidential over parliamentary system and, to support a transition to a non-democratic regime. However, recent empirical trends towards legislating constitutional changes to facilitate transitions to presidentialism and to non-democratic regimes suggest that existing explanations under-theorize the role of political parties in these phenomena. Recent empirical trends also challenge existing theories that posit that disciplined parties ameliorate the incentives of presidential regimes to reverse democracy. This project tests existing theories of presidential choice and democratic collapse and new theories regarding the role political parties play in these phenomena by collecting otherwise unavailable elite-level data through a survey of parliamentary candidates in Turkey. The ruling AKP Party's proposal to change Turkey's parliamentary system to a presidential one is viewed as a means for the AKP to create a one-party autocracy. Through this elite-survey project the PI seeks to understand the incentive structure for both AKP-MP candidates and opposition party MP candidates in the parliamentary/presidential transition question. This research will help inform literature on the choice between parliamentary and presidential and also literature on the extension of presidential term of office.

Outcomes Report for Grant #1545180

Presidentialism, Democratic Collapse and the Rise of a One-Party State: Turkey at the Crossroads

 

This project is designed to study two questions of theoretical and substantive important in Political Science:  (i) what influences political elites to support and oppose a transformation from a parliamentary democracy to a presidential democracy and, (ii) how do characteristics of democratic party organizations and party elites and, structural and international factors influence political elites in a democracy to support or oppose a transition to a non-democratic one-party state.  In order to study these questions, I proposed using the case of Turkey in 2015.  Turkey was going to hold parliamentary elections in June 2015.  While the ruling party argued a presidential system was better suited for addressing problems in the Turkish political system, opponents saw this as an attempt to transform Turkey into a one-party dictatorship. Public opinion on this change and public support for the ruling party was uncertain and the ruling party’s ability to win sufficient parliamentary seats to implement its proposal was jeopardized by the entry of a new pro-Kurdish party in the elections. For these reasons, Turkey at this time provided a highly suitable case for testing the validity of existing theories which explained why elites support presidential rather than parliamentary regimes and my own hypotheses regarding the effects of party organizations and individual characteristics on this choice.

 

Specific Objectives: In order to test existing theories and my hypotheses, I proposed to survey political elites – 250 candidates for parliamentary elections – in Turkey at this crucial time in Turkish politics. I requested funds to field this survey in the month before the June 7 2015 elections and, to conduct open-ended interviews with political elites and civil society organizations in July, 2015.

 

Major activities: Once I received the funds, I designed the sampling scheme and the survey instrument myself in English. I then hired FREKANS, a survey research consulting firm based in Istanbul to translate and field the survey for me. They successfully completed 300 interviews in the one month period. This dataset contains information on the demographic and political backgrounds of these candidates, their knowledge regarding their own constituencies and their opponents, their relationships with their own party organizations and, the level of support they were willing to extend for strengthening existing institutions such as courts and the media and, their support or opposition for changing Turkey to a presidential regime. In addition to the survey data, I also collected census information on the socioeconomic characteristics of all Turkish districts and the results of prior elections at the district level.

 

The survey was completed on June 6, 2015 and the dataset was sent to me the following week. Based on a preliminary analysis of these new data and on the existing literatures, I then contacted various parties and individuals to schedule open-ended face to face interviews on these issues. Finally, I spent 1 week in Turkey in July 2015 conducting interviews with mid-level and high level party leaders for all the major political parties, with leaders of legal and business associations and, with journalists and academics. This allowed me to supplement and enrich the findings from the preliminary analysis.

 

Training and Professional Development Opportunities: I started working with these data in late fall of 2015 in preparation for a second round of survey and to combine the Turkish case with similar data from Egyptian elections of 2011-12 that I had already collected.  I have started working on 2 papers and a book manuscript that use these data to address the theoretical questions that motivated this project. I have invited one of my graduate students, Amanda Fidalgo to collaborate with me on two of these papers. This is providing her with the opportunity to learn and apply IRT techniques using these survey questions to develop measures of individual authoritarianism for these elites in addition to learning about the design and analysis of survey data.

 

Products:  My graduate students and I will be submitting two research papers for presentation in the American Political Science conference in 2017 and in some smaller workshops. We hope to submit the first article for publication in an academic journal by December, 2016 and the second by March/April 2017.  I will be working on an original book manuscript which examines how party organizational features interact with individual characteristics of elites to shape their support or opposition to a presidential over a parliamentary system and, their support for building stronger democratic institutions.  I plan to work on this manuscript over this academic year and submit it to academic presses around August-September, 2017 for consideration for publication.  By the end of the next reporting period, I will have submitted at least two papers and possibly completed and submitted the book manuscript as well.
